items.title: The permutation group of Reed-Solomon codes over arbitrary points
items.authors: Eduardo Camps-Moreno, Jun Bo Lau, Hiram H. LÃ³pez, Welington Santos
items.institution: Virginia Tech, KU Leuven, University of Wisconsin-Stout
items.contributions: 1. Proves that the permutation group of a Reed-Solomon code is precisely the set of degree-one polynomials (affine permutations) that leave its set of evaluation points invariant. 2. Provides a straightforward, elementary algebraic proof for this characterization, applicable to arbitrary evaluation sets. 3. Generalizes and simplifies the proof for well-known special cases where the evaluation set is the entire finite field or the multiplicative group.
items.summary: This paper studies the permutation group (automorphism group) of Reed-Solomon codes. It proves that this group consists exactly of the affine permutations (polynomials of degree one) that map the code's evaluation set to itself. This result provides a simple, unified proof for previously known special cases and clarifies the structure of the code's symmetries for arbitrary evaluation points.

items.title: Modern Neuromorphic AI: From Intra-Token to Inter-Token Processing
items.authors: Osvaldo Simeone
items.institution: Northeastern University London (Intelligent Networked Systems Institute - INSI)
items.contributions: 1. Proposes a novel conceptual framework for analyzing modern neuromorphic AI through the lens of intra-token (feature-level) and inter-token (contextual) processing. 2. Systematically reviews the convergence of neuromorphic principles (e.g., sparse, discrete activations) with state-of-the-art AI architectures like state-space models and transformers. 3. Reviews and categorizes training methodologies for neuromorphic models, from surrogate gradients to local learning rules based on reinforcement learning.
items.summary: This paper addresses the high energy costs of modern AI by exploring the convergence of neuromorphic computing principles with contemporary architectures. It proposes a framework distinguishing between intra-token and inter-token processing to analyze how neuromorphic ideas like sparse activations and state dynamics are embodied in models such as transformers and state-space models. The main conclusion is that modern AI is increasingly adopting brain-inspired, energy-efficient neuromorphic principles for both processing types, offering a path toward more sustainable intelligent systems.

It achieves this through low-rank gradient projection and orthogonal superposition for transmission. Experiments on angle-of-arrival estimation show it outperforms baselines in efficiency while maintaining convergence under non-IID data.

items.institution: Zhejiang University, Xidian University, Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology (JAIST)
items.contributions: 1. Proposes a random multiplexing technique decoupled from physical channel structures, enabling application to arbitrary norm-bounded and spectrally convergent channel matrices. 2. Introduces a low-complexity cross-domain memory AMP (CD-MAMP) detector and derives optimal power allocations to minimize BER and maximize constrained capacity. 3. Investigates the optimal coding principle and proves the replica constrained-capacity optimality of the CD-MAMP detector for random multiplexing systems.
items.summary: This paper proposes a random multiplexing technique to overcome the limitations of traditional and emerging multiplexing schemes (like OFDM and OTFS) which rely on specific channel structures. The method decouples from the physical channel, uses a random transform to create an input-isotropic equivalent channel, and employs a low-complexity AMP-type detector to achieve near-optimal performance for arbitrary norm-bounded channels. The authors validate the approach with theoretical analysis and numerical results, demonstrating its robustness and versatility in dynamic wireless environments.

items.title: When Wires Can't Keep Up: Reconfigurable AI Data Centers Empowered by Terahertz Wireless Communications
items.authors: Chong Han, Mingjie Zhu, Wenqi Zhao, Ziming Yu, Guolong Huang, Guangjian Wang, Wen Tong, Wenjun Zhang
items.institution: Shanghai Jiao Tong University (inferred from author list and affiliations)
items.contributions: 1. Proposes a vision for a Terahertz Wireless Data Center (THz-WDC) to address the limitations of wired interconnects in AI clusters, defining performance targets like 1 Tbps/link and sub-50 ns latency. 2. Identifies and explores key enabling technologies for THz-WDC, including digital-twin orchestration, low-complexity beam manipulation, all-silicon transceivers, and analog baseband architectures. 3. Provides a numerical analysis comparing THz with optical and copper interconnects, identifying specific distance/throughput regimes where THz offers advantages, and outlines a roadmap for wireless-defined data centers.
items.summary: This paper proposes using Terahertz (THz) wireless communications to create reconfigurable, high-performance interconnects for AI data centers, overcoming the rigidity and inefficiency of traditional copper and optical wiring. It articulates technical requirements and explores enabling technologies like beam manipulation and silicon transceivers to achieve ultra-low latency and high energy efficiency. The analysis concludes that THz wireless links can surpass wired solutions in specific short-to-medium range scenarios, paving the way for dynamic and sustainable AI computing infrastructure.

Extended TGRS decoding to support codes with up to O(n^2) twists, far beyond the prior single-twist limit, and provided the first efficient decoder for Roth-Lempel codes. 3. Developed a comprehensive analytical framework, including the definition and study of symmetric probability measures, to analyze iterative decoding thresholds for coupled ensembles over any finite field on q-ary input memoryless symmetric channels (QMSCs). 3. Established a universal threshold saturation result, showing that the belief-propagation threshold of the coupled system saturates to a well-defined limit as coupling parameters increase.
items.summary: This paper investigates spatially coupled low-density parity-check (SC-LDPC) code ensembles over finite fields. It analyzes their minimum distance properties and develops a theoretical framework to prove that the belief-propagation decoding threshold for these codes on symmetric channels saturates to a well-defined limit as the coupling parameters increase.

items.title: Privacy-Preserving Semantic Communications via Multi-Task Learning and Adversarial Perturbations
items.authors: Yalin E. Sagduyu, Tugba Erpek, Aylin Yener, Sennur Ulukus
items.institution: Nexcepta, The Ohio State University, University of Maryland
items.contributions: 1. A deep learning-based semantic communication framework that jointly supports multiple receiver tasks (e.g., inference and reconstruction) while explicitly limiting semantic information leakage to an eavesdropper. 2. Formulation of the privacy problem as an iterative min-max optimization, where the legitimate transmitter-receiver pair is trained to degrade an adaptive eavesdropper's semantic inference performance. 3. Introduction of an auxiliary adversarial perturbation layer that superimposes a crafted signal on the transmitted waveform to degrade eavesdropper performance, even when the legitimate link is not co-trained against it.
items.summary: This paper addresses privacy leakage in semantic communications, where task-optimized representations can be exploited by eavesdroppers. The proposed method uses a min-max adversarial training framework and an auxiliary perturbation layer to protect semantic information. Evaluations on image datasets show the approach significantly reduces eavesdropper inference accuracy without harming legitimate receiver performance.

items.title: Infinite families of graphs and stable completion of arbitrary matrices, Part I
items.authors: Augustin Cosse
items.contributions: 1. Establishes a connection between matrix completability and specific graph patterns (unions of self-avoiding walks) in the support's lattice subgraph. 2. Provides deterministic constructions of graphs that guarantee unique and stable low-rank matrix completion for arbitrary entries. 3. Enables the design of infinite families of graphs for which exact completion is possible via the sum-of-squares hierarchy for any fixed-rank matrix.
items.summary: This paper studies deterministic constructions of bipartite graphs that guarantee the unique and stable completion of low-rank matrices from partial observations, regardless of the specific matrix values. The key idea is to relate completability to the presence of specific patterns (unions of self-avoiding walks) in the graph induced by the observed entries. The main result is a method to design infinite families of graphs where exact and stable completion is provably possible for any fixed-rank matrix using the sum-of-squares optimization hierarchy.

items.title: Throughput Optimization in UAV-Mounted RIS under Jittering and Imperfect CSI via DRL
items.authors: Anas K. Saeed, Mahmoud M. Salim, Ali Arshad Nasir, Ali H. Muqaibel
items.institution: King Fahd University of Petroleum and Minerals
items.contributions: 1. Formulated a stochastic nonconvex optimization problem for throughput maximization in a UAV-mounted RIS system under practical impairments of 3D UAV jitter and imperfect cascaded CSI. 2. Proposed a model-free DRL framework with a contextual bandit formulation, utilizing a differentiable feasibility layer to handle strict unit-modulus constraints and Monte Carlo estimation for the reward. 3. Instantiated the framework with constrained variants of DDPG and TD3 algorithms (without target networks) that achieve higher throughput than AO-WMMSE baselines under severe impairments and offer significantly faster online inference.
items.summary: This paper tackles the problem of maximizing throughput in a UAV-mounted RIS communication system under practical impairments like UAV jitter and imperfect channel knowledge. It proposes a deep reinforcement learning framework with constrained policy gradient algorithms to jointly optimize the base station's beamforming and the RIS's phase shifts. The results show the DRL approach outperforms conventional optimization methods under severe impairments and offers much faster online decision-making.

items.authors: Erik Lentz, Emily Ellwein, Bill Kay, Audun Myers, Cameron Mackenzie
items.contributions: 1. Proposes a novel information-theoretic interpretation of the Wigner-Ville transform for signal analysis. 2. Demonstrates the utility of the Wigner-Ville transform combined with Tsallis entropy for detecting and localizing signals in noisy backgrounds and measuring their information volumes. 3. Shows significant sensitivity advantages (over 15 dB) over energy-based detection methods in RF communications, especially for transient or weak signals.
items.summary: This paper reinterprets the classical Wigner-Ville transform as an information measurement tool for signal processing. By applying Tsallis entropy, the method detects and quantifies information in noisy radio-frequency signals, achieving over 15 dB sensitivity gain compared to energy-based detection without extensive training.

items.title: A New Decomposition Paradigm for Graph-structured Nonlinear Programs via Message Passing
items.authors: Kuangyu Ding, Marie Maros, Gesualdo Scutari
items.contributions: 1. Introduces MP-Jacobi, a novel decentralized framework that combines min-sum message passing with Jacobi block updates for graph-structured nonlinear programs, enabling single-hop communication and convergence on loopy graphs. 2. Establishes global linear convergence rates for strongly convex objectives, providing theoretical guidance on how curvature, coupling strength, and graph partitioning affect scalability. 3. Develops graph-compliant surrogate updates and a hyperedge-splitting scheme to reduce per-iteration computation/communication costs and extend the method to hypergraphs while preserving convergence.
items.summary: The paper proposes MP-Jacobi, a decentralized algorithm for solving graph-structured nonlinear programs by partitioning the graph into tree clusters and combining min-sum message passing within clusters with Jacobi-style updates for inter-cluster couplings. This design uses only single-hop communication and is proven to converge linearly for strongly convex problems. Experiments show it outperforms decentralized gradient baselines, offering a scalable primitive for graph optimization.

items.title: Coding-Logic Correspondence: Turning Information and Communication Networks into Logical Formulae via Hypergraph Heyting Algebra
items.authors: Cheuk Ting Li
items.institution: The Chinese University of Hong Kong
items.contributions: 1. Proposes a new model of information using confusion hypergraphs (hyperconfusions) instead of random variables. 2. Establishes that information modeled this way forms a Heyting algebra, enabling logical operations (conjunction, disjunction, implication). 3. Introduces a "coding-logic correspondence" that expresses communication network requirements as logical formulae, allowing direct computation of optimal coding schemes with cost given by hypergraph entropy.
items.summary: The paper proposes modeling information using confusion hypergraphs, which allows information to form a Heyting algebra and be manipulated with logical operations. This connection enables the requirements of communication networks (like network coding) to be expressed as logical formulae, from which optimal coding schemes can be directly computed, with the communication cost linked to hypergraph entropy. This establishes a novel correspondence between coding problems and logic, analogous to the Curry-Howard correspondence.

Develops a two-phase operation protocol for autonomous service classification and resource partitioning, and a utility-to-signaling ratio (USR) metric to quantify the performance-overhead tradeoff. 3. Formulates a USR maximization problem and addresses it with a multi-agent deep reinforcement learning (MADRL) framework to handle the distributed optimization and incomplete channel state information.
items.summary: This paper proposes an elastic network topology to flexibly support distributed integrated sensing and communication services by dynamically aggregating cell-centric networks into cell-free federations. A two-phase protocol and a utility-to-signaling ratio metric are introduced, and the resulting optimization problem is solved using a multi-agent deep reinforcement learning approach. Simulation results validate the effectiveness of the proposed design and algorithm.

items.authors: Brani Vidakovic
items.contributions: 1. Introduces a new entropy-normalized complexity measure for binary words, defined as the ratio of Kolmogorov complexity to empirical entropy, to separate intrinsic descriptive complexity from symbol imbalance. 2. items.summary: This paper introduces a new measure of complexity for binary words by normalizing Kolmogorov complexity with the word's empirical entropy, aiming to isolate intrinsic algorithmic structure from the combinatorial effect of imbalanced symbol frequencies. The authors prove that for random sequences under certain measures, this adjusted complexity converges to one, and show that the regularity of the measure is crucial. The framework connects Kolmogorov complexity, entropy, and randomness, with potential applications in randomness testing and structured data analysis.
